articles.headline: The Stark Reality of Israel’s Fight in Gaza
articles.snippet: Israel has failed to achieve its two primary goals of the war, while the suffering of Palestinians erodes support even among its allies.
articles.abstract: Israel has failed to achieve its two primary goals of the war, while the suffering of Palestinians erodes support even among its allies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Israel’s military operations in Gaza have weakened Hamas. Most Hamas battalions have been degraded and are scattered. Thousands of its members have been killed, and at least one senior military leader has been eliminated.
articles.byline: By Julian E. Barnes, Adam Goldman, Eric Schmitt and Adam Rasgon

articles.headline: Universities Struggle as Pro-Palestinian Demonstrations Grow
articles.snippet: Dozens were arrested Monday at N.Y.U. and Yale, but officials there and at campuses across the country are running out of options to corral protests that are expected to last the rest of the school year.
articles.abstract: Dozens were arrested Monday at N.Y.U. and Yale, but officials there and at campuses across the country are running out of options to corral protests that are expected to last the rest of the school year.
articles.lead_paragraph: At New York University, the police swept in to arrest protesting students on Monday night, ending a standoff with the school’s administration.

articles.headline: Trapped and Starving, 2 Families in Gaza Try to Keep Their Children Alive
articles.snippet: The United Nations says famine is likely to set in by May. For those living under Israel’s attacks and a crippling blockade, every day is a race against time.
articles.abstract: The United Nations says famine is likely to set in by May. For those living under Israel’s attacks and a crippling blockade, every day is a race against time.
articles.lead_paragraph: Born in wartime, the baby had not eaten in more than a day, his father said — no formula, no nothing. His parents had already spent the last of their money on food, sold his mother’s gold jewelry to buy milk and begged water from other evacuees to mix the powdered formula. Now even that was gone.
articles.byline: By Vivian Yee and Bilal Shbair

articles.headline: Slide Over, Auntie: Young Chinese Find Tasty Meals in Senior Canteens
articles.snippet: The community canteens, offering huge plates for a dollar or two, have become popular among penny-pinching young professionals.
articles.abstract: The community canteens, offering huge plates for a dollar or two, have become popular among penny-pinching young professionals.
articles.lead_paragraph: Inside a canteen for seniors in downtown Shanghai, a worker brandishing a sponge inched closer to Maggie Xu, 29, as she was finishing her rice and garlic-and-oil-soaked broccoli. Ms. Xu ignored her.

articles.headline: In Silicon Valley, You Can Be Worth Billions and It’s Not Enough
articles.snippet: Andreas Bechtolsheim, the first investor in Google, has an estimated $16 billion fortune. He recently settled charges that he engaged in insider trading for a profit of $415,726.
articles.abstract: Andreas Bechtolsheim, the first investor in Google, has an estimated $16 billion fortune. He recently settled charges that he engaged in insider trading for a profit of $415,726.
articles.lead_paragraph: Andreas Bechtolsheim doesn’t like to waste time. The entrepreneur made one of the most celebrated investments in the history of Silicon Valley — the initial $100,000 that bankrolled a search engine called Google in 1998 — while on the way to work one morning. It took just a few minutes.

articles.headline: ‘Pay Later’ Lenders Have an Issue With Credit Bureaus
articles.snippet: Firms like Experian and TransUnion say it is time for “buy now, pay later” loans to appear on consumer credit reports. The lenders aren’t ready to sign on.
articles.abstract: Firms like Experian and TransUnion say it is time for “buy now, pay later” loans to appear on consumer credit reports. The lenders aren’t ready to sign on.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shoppers in recent years have embraced “buy now, pay later” loans as an easy, interest-free way to purchase everything from sweaters to concert tickets.
articles.byline: By Jordyn Holman and Ben Casselman

articles.headline: In Ukraine, New American Technology Won the Day. Until It Was Overwhelmed.
articles.snippet: Project Maven was meant to revolutionize modern warfare. But the conflict in Ukraine has underscored how difficult it is to get 21st-century data into 19th-century trenches.
articles.abstract: Project Maven was meant to revolutionize modern warfare. But the conflict in Ukraine has underscored how difficult it is to get 21st-century data into 19th-century trenches.
articles.lead_paragraph: The idea triggered a full-scale revolt on the Google campus.
